metadata.case_name: Sardar Kapur Singh v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant Sardar Kapur Singh admitted to Indian Civil Service upon competitive examination held at Delhi in 1931.
After training in UK, returned to India in November 1933, posted as Assistant Commissioner, Ferozepore, Punjab; served in various capacities 1933-1947.
In July 1947, posted as Deputy Commissioner at Dharamsala; continued till February 11, 1948, then transferred to Hoshiarpur, continued till few days before April 14, 1949.
On April 13, 1949, served with suspension order by Government of East Punjab.

On May 5, 1950, appellant submitted representation to President of India protesting suspension, praying removal from control of Punjab Government and disciplinary action by Government of India outside Punjab.

On May 18, 1950, Government of East Punjab appointed Mr. Eric Weston, Chief Justice of East Punjab High Court as Enquiry Commissioner under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, to enquire into twelve articles of charges; notice issued to appellant.
On November 5, 1950, at suggestion of Enquiry Commissioner, Government withdrew charges 11 and 12; enquiry proceeded on remaining ten charges.
Charges 1,2,7,8,9,10 related to misappropriation of sums received/entrusted, failure to account (Dharamsala period).
Charge 3: Attempts to secure firearm from engineer, unauthorised retention, procuration of sanction for purchase.
Charge 4: Granting sanction under Alienation of Land Act for sale of land by agriculturist to non-agriculturist, appellant beneficiary, abuse of authority (Dharamsala).
Charge 5: Grant of contract to Sardar Raghbir Singh for firewood supply without tenders, high rates, acceptance of inferior wood causing Rs.30,000 loss (Hoshiarpur).
Charge 6: Purchase of motor car abusing authority, flouting govt order March 21, 1949, bogus sale to Ms. Massand Motors, deciding appeal in which personally interested (Hoshiarpur).
Enquiry: State evidence at Dharamsala July 31-Aug 21, 1950; resumed Simla Sep 5-Oct 23, 1950.
Appellant filed defence witnesses list Oct 27, 1950; written statement; gave evidence Nov 28-Dec 5, 1950; defence witnesses Dec 5-28, 1950; case closed Dec 28, 1950.
Post Dec 28, 1950: Appellant filed applications/affidavits; adjourned Jan 2, 1951 for winter; resumed Mar 12, 1951; formal evidence of two witnesses; arguments; closed.

Enquiry Commissioner report May 14, 1951: Proved misappropriation charges 1,2,7,8,9,10 (aggregate Rs.16,734-11-6 unaccounted); no finding on 3,4; adverse on charge 6 (appeal decision); charge 5 dishonest preference causing loss.
Feb 11, 1952: Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs supplied report copy to appellant; President opined unsuitable, provisionally decided dismissal; opportunity to show cause within 21 days.
Appellant submitted 321-page representation May 7, 1952.
President consulted Union Public Service Commission; dismissed appellant July 27, 1953.
Appellant filed Art.226 petition in East Punjab High Court challenging proceedings, report, seeking reinstatement; dismissed by Chief Justice Bhandari and Justice Khosla.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate of fitness from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Punjab Government had jurisdiction to direct enquiry as appellant was member of Indian Civil Service not employed under Punjab Government.
Whether enquiry could only be under r.55 of Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, not under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850.
Whether enquiry under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 violated equal protection clause (Art.14).
Whether Enquiry Commissioner violated rules of natural justice by not allowing sufficient opportunity to examine witnesses and produce evidence.
Whether President deprived appellant of reasonable opportunity under Art.311 by not directing viva voce examination of witnesses and not giving oral hearing.

petitioner_arguments.text: Enquiry could not be directed by Punjab Government as appellant was member of Indian Civil Service and not employed under Punjab Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Independence Act s.10(2); Government of India Act s.240(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: Enquiry could only be held under r.55 of Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, not under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850.
Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 violates Art.14 as more stringent than r.55.
Enquiry Commissioner did not allow sufficient opportunity to examine witnesses and produce documentary evidence.
President did not give reasonable opportunity by not directing viva voce evidence and oral submission.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant was employed under East Punjab Government at time of enquiry direction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Public Servants Inquiries Act s.2, s.23

respondent_arguments.text: r.55 is without prejudice to Public Servants Inquiries Act; enquiry under Act sufficient.
Procedures under Act and r.55 substantially similar; no violation of Art.14 or natural justice.
President could rely on Enquiry Commissioner's recorded evidence; written representation sufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant employed under East Punjab Government; State authorised to direct enquiry under s.2 Public Servants Inquiries Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in Constitution abrogates State's authority; ICS members not excluded.

court_reasoning.text: r.55 without prejudice to 1850 Act; enquiry under Act complies, no need for separate r.55 enquiry.
Procedures under Act and r.55 substantially same; no discrimination under Art.14 unless prejudice shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prejudice to appellant; enquiry fair.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiry not vitiated by natural justice violation; appellant examined 82 witnesses, produced documents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court view affirmed; sufficient opportunity given.

court_reasoning.text: President not bound to hear viva voce evidence after full enquiry; written 321-page representation adequate under Art.311.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasonable opportunity provided; oral hearing not necessary.

holdings.text: State Government authorised to hold enquiry under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850 against ICS member employed under it.
Enquiry under 1850 Act sufficient compliance with r.55; no separate enquiry needed.
No violation of Art.14; procedures equivalent, no prejudice.
President's order valid; reasonable opportunity under Art.311 given via written representation.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. A. Venkataraman v. The Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: r.55 lays down procedure including under 1850 Act or rule itself.

precedents_cited.case_name: Khem Chand v. The Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains reasonable opportunity under Art.311; no repetition of enquiry stage.

precedents_cited.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall
precedents_cited.relevance: Opportunity after definite conclusion on charges and punishment; no repetition if prior enquiry fair.

statutes_cited.name: Public Servants (Inquiries) Act, 1850
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorises formal public enquiry into misbehaviour of superior public servants; procedure followed valid.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for disciplinary enquiry without prejudice to 1850 Act; alternative to Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.311 reasonable opportunity; Art.314 preserves pre-Constitution rights; no violation.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act
statutes_cited.relevance: ICS members not dismissible by subordinate authority.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Independence Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Preserves conditions of service for Crown civil servants.

statutes_cited.name: Alienation of Land Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge 4 involved abuse in granting sanction.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition, confirming validity of enquiry under Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, no natural justice violation, and President's dismissal order compliant with Art.311.

key_quotes.text: 'Without prejudice to the provisions of the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, no order of dismissal... unless..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies r.55 allows enquiry under Act as alternative.

key_quotes.text: The rule apparently means that an order of dismissal... shall not be passed without an enquiry either according to the procedure prescribed by the Public Servants Inquiries Act, 1850, or the procedure prescribed by the Rule.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Discrimination is not practised merely because resort is had to one of two alternative sources of authority, unless it is shown that the procedure adopted operated to the prejudice of the public servant concerned.
key_quotes.speaker: court
